entry.title: A Bayesian Workflow with PyMC and ArviZ
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Corrie Bartelheimer

Track:PyData Bayesian Modelling has several advantages such as the handling of uncertainty. While the advantages are well known, implementing a Bayesian model can be a bit more involved and some care needs to be taken to check whether the model converged.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/RRLRYG Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Does hate sound the same in all languages?
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Andrada Pumnea

Track:PyData How might we make social media safer and more inclusive? Tackling hate speech online is not easy, especially if it’s in a language less circulated. This talk describes detecting hate speech in Romanian from dataset creation to hate speech model.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/QA3EVU Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Friend or Foe: Comparison of R & Python in Data Wrangling & Visualization
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Yuta Kanzawa

Track:PyData R and Python are partially overlapping but different as a whole: community and language. Still, comparing them in their common fields such as data wrangling and visualisation, useRs and Pythonistas will deepen mutual understanding.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/9D3JQC Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Interpretable Machine Learning: How to make black box...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Alexander Engelhardt

Track:PyData Complex machine learning models make better predictions, but at the cost of turning into an unexplainable black-box model. In this talk, we'll look into a framework that allows us to explain why a model makes a specific prediction.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/ZKXNTB Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Law, ethics and machine learning - a curious ménage...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Dr. Benjamin Werthmann

Track:PyData The talk addresses how law and ethics can provide a framework for the “machines on the rise” that ensures fairness and societal acceptance while not interfering (too much) with the drive behind the advancement of a powerful technology.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/9VGGLP Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Lessons Learned as a Product Manager in Data Science
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Tereza Iofciu

Track:PyData The fun part about data science is that no two people really agree on the definition of the data scientist role. So how does the role of product manager in data science look like?

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/TS7TZF Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Leveraging the advantages of Bayesian Methods to build a data science product using PyMC3
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Korbinian Kuusisto

Track:PyData Bayesian models offer greater theoretical advantages compared to non-probabilistic methods, and also allow for more flexible model design. But how can one leverage these theoretical advantages to build a successful data science product?

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/WZWTVB Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Loss Function Theory 101
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: David Wölfle

Track:PyData This talk covers the theoretical background behind two common loss functions, mean squared error and cross entropy, including why they are used for machine learning at all, and what limitations you should keep in mind.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/JFEQY8 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Machine learning with little data - from digital twin to...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Andreas Hantsch

Track:PyData This talk is about the coupling of a digital twin model and a machine learning predictive maintenance algorithm in order to be able to detect anomalies in the operation of a not well-known hardware system.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/UMWRYD Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Making the complex simple in data viz
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Tania Vasilikioti

Track:PyData Creating graphics that convey the desired message, are easily interpretable, but also beautiful can be a daunting task. This talk will demonstrate how to use The Grammar of Graphics framework to conceptualize the elements of any graphic, in Python.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/NC8VVA Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Professional Development and Career Progression for Data Scientists
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Noa Tamir

Track:PyData In this talk you will learn how to level up your skills, and develop your your career using on the job opportunities, as well as open source contributions

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/E3LFDL Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Rethinking Open Source in the Era of Cloud & Machine Learning
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Peter Wang

Track:PyData By some measures, Open Source is a wildly successful and crucial part of many areas of modern technology. However, the ’sustainability crisis’ and the age of cloud computing have threatened its core mechanisms. Peter will present some alternative ways of looking at this crucial moment in the evolution of the open source movement, and suggest some ways to think about the future of open source.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/GGR9ZM Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Take control of your hearing: Accessible methods...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Peggy Sylopp, Aislyn Rose

Track:PyData Have you ever wanted more control over what you do or don't hear? This talk explores the potential of Python, deep learning, and open databases to bring you towards that goal, without needing expensive licenses or software.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/JZW9HE Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: The Sound of Silence: Online Misogyny and How we Model It
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Teresa Ingram

Track:PyData Female-identifying people are being attacked and silenced online. Social media platforms act as neutral bodies and law enforcement can’t stop the abuse. When you can’t trust that your safety will be protected online, what can you do? We say, Opt Out.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/JUQMXE Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Transforming a Legacy System into a Bias-Mitigating AI...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Avaré Stewart

Track:PyData We present Phoenix, a modernization of a legacy, German rule-based system based on Tesseract and SpaCy, and uses AI Fairness 360 to build tunable, Bias-Minimizing AI solutions to offer payment incentives to debtors.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/PMDFA3 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Tutorial: Decentralized and Privacy-Preserving ML via TensorFlow Federated
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Peter Kairouz, Amlan Chakraborty

Track:PyData Federated Learning is a technology to train machine learning models and run data analytics on decentralized data. This tutorial will demonstrate step-by-step how to train largescale TensorFlow models and custom computations in federated environments.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/WRPFUC Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Tutorial: Managing the end-to-end machine learning lifecycle with MLFlow
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Tobias Sterbak

Track:PyData Machine learning requires experimenting with datasets, data preparation steps, and algorithms. Deploy models to a production system and retrain it on new data. MLflow is an open source platform for managing the end-to-end machine learning lifecycle.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/PC38WB Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Tutorial: Using machine learning for Level Generation in Snake (video-game)
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Filipe Silva

Track:PyData As a practical example, this tutorial uses machine learning models to predict where to best place the apple in Snake. By using datasets that contain different plays we can obtain different game experiences or models that can adapt to the style of a player.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/VCSBUY Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Version Control for Data Science
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Alessia Marcolini

Track:PyData Are you versioning your Machine Learning project as you would do in a traditional software project? How are you keeping track of changes in your datasets?

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/PPGWXL Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Why you don't see many real-world applications of...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Yurii Tolochko

Track:PyData Reinforcement learning is the closest thing to a general AI system that we have. When it works, that is. The problem is, it often doesn’t. In this talk we will discuss the difficulties of RL as well as what to look for in the future.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/GTHCWX Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Your Name is Invalid!
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Miroslav Šedivý

Track:PyData About people with first names, middle names, last names, one-word names, multiple names, and changing names, about names with characters beyond ASCII, and about using Python to handle them correctly, because names of people cannot be invalid.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/ZNA8WN Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: 10 Years of Automated Category Classification for Product Data
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Johannes Knopp

Track:PyData 10 years ago we built a classifier for categorizing product data. Let's take a journey through the lessons we learned over the years about building, maintaining, and modernizing the category classifier.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/FDVFHX Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: A Tour of JupyterLab Extensions
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Jeremy Tuloup

Track:PyData JupyterLab can be extended via third-party extensions written by developers from the Jupyter community.

This is a tour of 20 of these extensions, in 20 minutes. Demos included!

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/EH7FWD Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Active Learning with Bayesian Nonnegative Matrix Factorization...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Gönül Aycı

Track:PyData In most of the systems, collecting data is not always free. I will talk about an approach for a matrix completion problem that learns a distribution of data where information is incomplete or collecting it has a cost.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/ZBEEM3 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Are you sure about that?! Uncertainty Quantification in AI
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Florian Wilhelm

Track:PyData There is a strong need in many AI applications to state the certainty about their predictions. This talk elaborates on different ways to perform uncertainty quantification in deep learning and classical methods.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/WQMPSW Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Avoiding ML FOBO
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Rachel Berryman, Dânia Meira

Track:PyData Everyday there is a new package or algorithm to use- it can be hard to determine what is useful and what is only hype. The speakers offer a practical roadmap and checklist to help you cut through the hype and focus on developing useful ML products.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/KC99NY Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Birds of a feather flock together - Tracking pigeons with...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Neslihan Edes

Track:PyData In this talk I want to demonstrate how to use OpenCV to implement basic animal movement tracking use cases. And everything without any fancy machine learning or neuronal networks ;)

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/T7EEEB Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Current affairs, updates, and the roadmap of scikit-learn and...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Adrin Jalali

Track:PyData As a scikit-learn core developer, I'd give an update on recent changes, current affairs, and the roadmap of the package and the community packages included in scikit-learn-contrib. I'd also briefly talk about how new method proposals are evaluated.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/X7FSX9 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Dash: Interactive Data Visualization Web Apps with no Javascript
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Dom Weldon

Track:PyData Interactive web pages and visualizations with no JavaScript? What could go wrong? What you can, can't, should and probably shouldn't do with plotly/Dash.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/R7PELL Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Data Literacy for Managers
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Alexander CS Hendorf

Track:PyData Artificial Intelligence need to be better understood in enterprises. Close the communications gap between engineers and management. Making data litteracy happen in your organisation.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/WUEBKT Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Detecting and Analyzing Solar Panels in Switzerland using...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Martin Christen

Track:PyData We present a novel method for detecting solar panels and its geometry on aerial imagery. The goal is to know the exact locations, dimensions and potential of every solar installation in Switzerland.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/RJCW8U Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Embrace uncertainty! Why to go beyond point estimators for...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Stefan Maier

Track:PyData Usually, uncertainties of Machine Learning predictions are just regarded as a sign of poor prediction accuracy or as a consequence of lacking input features. This talk illustrates how modeling uncertainties can improve ML based decisions.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/QHNEFT Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Equivariance in CNNs: how generalising the weight-sharing...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Marysia Winkels

Track:PyData In this talk, we will explore how the weight-sharing property of the convolutional layer can be generalised to achieve equivariance towards transformations beyond just translation, how to implement this, and the results on real-world data.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/RAS8UK Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Gaussian Process for Time Series Analysis
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Dr. Juan Orduz

Track:PyData The aim of this talk is to introduce the notion of Gaussian process and describe how to use it to solve regressions problems and time series forecasting.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/KNLNBB Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Gaussian Progress
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Vincent Warmerdam

Track:PyData This talk is an attempt at explaining the power of the Gaussian[tm] by stepping up the ladder from Naive Bayes to Mixtures to Neural Mixtures to Gaussian Processes.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/WDAANU Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: How strong is my opponent? Using Bayesian methods for skill...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Darina Goldin

Track:PyData Being able to correctly estimate a competitors' skill is a crucial question in sport forecasting and matchmaking. This talk will provide an overview of the three most common algorithms for this task: Elo, Glicko2 and Trueskill.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/3NUA9T Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: How to write tests that need a lot of data?
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Sander Kooijmans

Track:PyData In this talk Sander explains how you can write unit and integration tests that need a lot of data. As an example Sander shows how to test code of a warehouse management system (WMS). This is not about big-data, though.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/P9ZZB3 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Panel: Turn any notebook into a deployable dashboard
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Philipp Rudiger

Track:PyData Quickly turn your existing analyses built on the PyData stack into shareable, standalone apps and dashboards using the new open-source [Panel](http://panel.pyviz.org) library without learning the details of web development.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/ZT9NY9 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Should I stay or should I go? Optimal exercise decisions...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Benedikt Rudolph

Track:PyData This talk presents a Python implementation of the Longstaff-Schwartz algorithm for financial exercise option valuation. The technical problems of optimal exercise decisions and exercise option valuation are demonstrated using code examples.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/MAPYAH Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: skorch: A scikit-learn compatible neural network library...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Benjamin Bossan

Track:PyData This talk is about the open source package [skorch](https://github.com/skorch-dev/skorch), a wrapper library that allows you to combine the best of sklearn and PyTorch. It covers when it makes sense to use skorch and highlights interesting features.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/NMXSE7 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Tackle the problems that really matter - leverage...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Eva Schreyer, Lisa Zäuner

Track:PyData Data Science for Social Good Berlin (DSSG) brings together data scientist volunteers and nonprofit organisations that need support in tackling various data challenges. In this talk we will tell you how data science can be used for social good.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/PZVHP9 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Tools that help you get your experiments under control
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Katharina Rasch

Track:PyData There is now a wealth of tools that support data science best practices (e.g. tracking experiments, versioning data). Let’s take a look at which tools are available and which ones might be right for your project.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/CWMAE7 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Tutorial: Fairness in decision-making with AI: a practical guide & hands-on tutorial using Aequitas
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Pedro Saleiro

Track:PyData In this tutorial, we are going to deep dive into algorithmic fairness, from metrics and definitions to practical case studies, including bias audits using Aequitas (http://github.com/dssg/aequitas) in real policy problems where AI is being used.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/FAYUEK Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Tutorial: Quantum computing with Python
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: James Wootton

Track:PyData Frameworks for quantum computing are a new way to use Python for cutting-edge science, and to plan for future applications of this new technology. This session will serve as an introduction to quantum computing as a whole, and also to Qiskit, the most well-developed and well-used quantum Python framework.

And to make sure I don't get too complex, we'll do it all on a microcontroller!

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/RE99DB Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Using adversarial samples to break and robustify your...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Irina Vidal Migallón

Track:PyData We will cover several techniques to expose weaknesses and robustify neural network models for computer vision, from basic precautions to more advanced adversarial training.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/GKHSBP Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Using Overhead Video Capture to Analyse Grouping Behaviour of...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Nelson Mooren

Track:PyData I built upon Python's OpenCV library to detect locations of dancers in a silent disco, using their headphone lights as a proxy and performed network analysis to investigate their grouping behaviour based on the playlists people were listening to.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/RRPC79 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Want to have a positive social impact as a data scientist?
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Ellen König

Track:PyData Discover your individual approach towards more positive social impact by conducting experiments. I'll show you how! I’ll also share my learnings from doing such experiments over the last 15 years.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/JSJLG9 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: AI Intentions and Code Completion
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Vasily Korf

Track:PyData Datalore supports intentions – code suggestions based on what you’ve just written. They cover a wide range of situations from generating code to warnings and optimization suggestions.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/L998EU Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Algo.Rules - How do we get the ethics into the code?
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Carla Hustedt

Track:PyData In the keynote I will present our Algo.Rules, 9 rules for the design of algorithmic systems and address the questions “What standards of quality should algorithms be held to?” and “How can we make sure that these standards are actually being implemented?”

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/ZEEMKS Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Applying deployment oriented mindset for building Machine...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Marianna Diachuk

Track:PyData Developing ensemble model with hundreds of features? And getting stuck for months trying to deploy the model and fighting with data inconsistency and bugs? This talk will introduce the way to build the development process with deployment in mind.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/LGC8XP Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Automated Feature Engineering and Selection in Python
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Franziska Horn

Track:PyData Careful feature engineering and selection can be just as important as choosing the right ML model & hyperparameters. I will present several options for automating the feature engineering and selection process with a focus on the autofeat library.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/Q7KLXV Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Automating feature engineering for supervised learning?...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Thorben Jensen

Track:PyData Feature engineering is crucial for supervised learning (SL), but labor-intensive. Automating this task is less established, compared to other steps of SL. We therefore present and compare approached and open-source libraries for automating this task.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/7EEPKX Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Creating an Interactive ML Conference Showcase
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Harald Bosch

Track:PyData Our goal is to create a simple yet interactive showcase for computer vision using a Python notebook. In a trade fair setup, we want to learn new object classes quickly using very few training examples. Thus, we rely on pretrained neural networks for

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/MMXQUC Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Fighting fraud: finding duplicates at scale
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Alexey Grigorev

Track:PyData We present a duplicate detection system that we use to fight fraud in online classifieds. The system uses machine learning to analyze both text and images of 10 million ads daily and stop fraudulent listings before they do any harm.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/7PHMWA Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Hide Code, Minimize Dependencies, Boost Performance - The...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Tilman Krokotsch

Track:PyData PyTorch makes developing, training and debugging deep neural networks convenient. Learn how to export your trained model using its just-in-time (JIT) compiler to hide your network architecture, minimize code dependencies and use it in the C++ API.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/8N37P9 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: How to choose better colors for your data visualizations
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Daniel Ringler

Track:PyData Everybody is doing colorful charts with Python libraries such as matplotlib and bokeh but most people never change the basic configuration. This talk will teach you the basics of color theory to help you choose the right colors of your charts.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/QE3UUQ Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Julia for Python
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Simon Danisch

Track:PyData Julia is a new Language, that is fast, high level, dynamic and optimized for Data Science. But due to its young age, it might not be for everyone yet. Learn about Julia's strengths and how you can integrate it in your Python workflow!

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/ALEMND Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Kartothek - Table management for cloud object stores powered...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Florian Jetter

Track:PyData Efficient data storage is an integral part of successful data applications. Cloud object stores prove to be an efficient choice but come with downsides when storing structured, tabular data. There is a way out, though.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/CXYNHX Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Dr. Tania Allard

Track:PyData How many times have you developed a model or a data application and tested it locally or in a staging environment just to find out that it breaks in production? This is a common issue faced by thousands of data scientists around the globe. As the wor

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/AEAT3E Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Privacy-preserving Machine Learning for text processing
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Sarah Diot-Girard

Track:PyData Privacy is something we all care about, but when it is time to put our principles into application, it is not so trivial, especially when working with text. This talk aims at presenting a few options to handle privacy when dealing with text.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/MF9DAV Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Production-level data pipelines that make everyone happy using... | PyData Austin 2019
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Yetunde Dada

Track:PyData Learn how easy it is to apply software engineering principles to your data science and data engineering code. Expect an overview of Kedro, a library that implements best practices for data pipelines with an eye towards productionizing ML models.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/FXUYQ9 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Time Series Anomaly Detection for Bottling Machine
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Andrea Spichtinger

Track:PyData This talk discusses time series anomaly detection methods for predictive maintenance of machines in bottling plants and their implemention on AWS edge devices.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/7XCL3Z Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Time series modelling with probabilistic...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Sean Matthews, Jannes Quer

Track:PyData This talk focuses on a Bayesian approach of advanced time-series forecasting in the case of small data. We describe the stages of modelling from simple smoothing to advanced forecasting by applying Gaussian Processes and State Space Models.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/AX9CSK Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Sandrine Pataut

Track:PyData This session will be an exposition of data wrangling with pandas and machine learning with scikit-learn for Python Programmers. This hands-on workshop will cover a classification project, from importing the data to evaluating model performance.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/9ZAA9T Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Caio Miyashiro

Track:PyData This tutorial describes the intuition behind Hidden Markov Models, with less mathematical formulas and with an application on Music Analytics - Chord Recognition

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/YXNDB9 Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Visualizing Interactive Graph Networks in Python
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Jan-Benedikt Jagusch

Track:PyData In this talk you will learn how to visualize graph networks in Python, using networkx, traitlets, ipywidgets and plotly. The resulting plot will be fully interactive, which makes it easy to filter edges, find nodes by their name and update the graph's layout.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/HFKNUW Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: vtext: text processing in Rust with Python bindings
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Roman Yurchak

Track:PyData In this we talk present how to write Python extensions in Rust, and discusse advantages and limitation of such approach. We then illustrate this approach on the vtext project, that aims to be a high-performance library for text processing.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/ALRGXS Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Where Linguistics meets Natural Language Processing
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Mariana Capinel

Track:PyData This talk explains how linguistics describes language - via phonetics-phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics and pragmatics. We will combine linguistic concepts with models through examples for NLP newbies.

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/SGPLXB Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde

entry.title: Why you should (not) train your own BERT model for...
entry.summary:
Description

Speaker: Marianne Stecklina

Track:PyData Language models like BERT can capture general language knowledge and transfer it to new data and tasks. However, applying a pre-trained BERT to non-English text has limitations. Is training from scratch a good (and feasible) way to overcome them?

Recorded at the PyConDE & PyData Berlin 2019 conference. https://pycon.de

More details at the conference page: https://de.pycon.org/program/YAJRGX Twitter: https://twitter.com/pydataberlin Twitter: https://twitter.com/pyconde
